casebody.data:
APPELLATE DIVISION OF THE MUNICIPAL COURT OF THE CITY OF BOSTON EDWARD B. LUNN, TR., ET AL. vs. SAMUEL GOLDKRAND.

Suffolk, ss. Municipal Court of the City of Boston

Argued November 17, 1941 Opinion filed December 31, 1941. Present: Putnam, G. J., Bakron & Cohen, JJ. 8. B. Stem, for the Plaintiff. P. Lipper, for the Defendant. Putnam, C. J.

On March 2,1940, there was duly recorded a chattel mortgage from the House of Liederman, Inc., to the plaintiff. This mortgage covered all the mortgagor’s personal property in or about 169-171 Norfolk Avenue, Boston. Four Ford motor vehicles were specifically described therein as follows: “1 1934 Ford Panel Truck *43#18-3321972. 1 1934 Ford Panel Truck #18-2915825. 1 1936 Ford Panel Truck (Dual Wheel) #18-868751. 1 1936 Ford Panel Truck (Dual Wheel) # 18-881942.”

On or about September 7, 1940, the House of Liederman, Inc., sold to the E. & L. Operating Company a Ford motor vehicle described, in the E. & L. Operating Company’s application to the registry of motor vehicles for registration, as follows; “Make — Ford. Type — 157" chassis & cab Ford panel truck. Tear of Manufacture 1936. Engine No. 18-3321972. From whom acquired — House of Liederman, Boston, Sept. 7, 1940,” and the registrar registered a vehicle under that description and assigned it number A18512.

On December 12, 1940, counsel for one Hoifenberg obtained from a justice of this court leave to attach a “1936 Ford truck, registration #A18512 — located at 169 Norfolk Avenue, Boston”. The defendant named in that writ was E. & L. Operating Company. On December 14, 1940, by virtue of that writ the defendant in the case at bar, a constable, attached and took possession of a Ford dual wheel panel truck, 1936 chassis and cab, serial #18-3321972, registration #A18512. On December 18, 1940, and on subsequent dates, the plaintiff in the case at bar made written demand upon the defendant, claiming the truck under the chattel mortgage described above. There being no response to this demand the plaintiff brought this action of tort for conversion.

The trial judge found for the plaintiff for the value of the truck and made the following express written findings:

“I find as a fact that the motor vehicle here in question to have been sufficiently described in the mortgage; that said description is not misleading; and that said motor vehicle could be readily identified from such description *44irrespective of the inaccurate recital as to year of manufacture or of model year appearing* therein.”

The principles applicable to this case are well settled. A general description of personal property in a mortgage is sufficient to include articles which can be identified and which were intended to be covered by it. The test in such case is that, where the property can be readily identified after rejecting false or inaccurate recitals, effect may be given to the mortgage. E. M. Blunt Co. v. Giles, 288 Mass. 515. The case made by this report is so plainly distinguishable from Wise v. Kennedy, 248 Mass. 83, as to require no discussion. In view of the undisputed facts, plus the findings of the trial judge, none of the defendant’s requests for rulings could have been given.

Report dismissed.
